of narcissistic bullshit.content: An odd example as if it was written by an angry misogynistic guy or something. I’m just saying...
(of a person or their behavior) primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics: _she's nothing but a mercenary little gold digger._

She told us there were liberals living next door as if we would think that was bad thing. “They didn't like the sign in our yard.” Funny how easy it is to be so full of yourself that you think others would have to agree with you. You're on the right side of history after all. How could anyone not agree?

an obvious case.content: Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.

She told us there were liberals living next door as if we would think that was bad thing. “They didn't like the sign in our yard.” Funny how easy it is to be so full of yourself that you think others would have to agree with you. You're on the right side of history after all. How could anyone not agree?

find your way back home.content: It was an old step van and the passenger seat wasn’t anchored. As my father drove, the seat slid forward then back then forward again. What a ride! I’m [guessing](shatters.md) I was about 10 or 11-years-old then based on the fact that Tony was with us in the van. He was a guy my father helped to immigrate from Cuba (in 1959?). We were on the way to [the bay](the%20bay.md).
When we discovered Sliding Rock, we had not bathed for days camping up in the mountains. The cold plunge pool below was totally rejuvenating.

in depressing times.content: So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.

content: Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.
Click on a post in the sidebar to view it. Click on a paragraph to view related ideas.
The mobile version works best in landscape mode.

We lived above the sub shop. My parents had opened one of area’s first, specializing in [Italian subs](sub.md), Philly steak sandwiches, Sicilian pizza, and other goodies. It’s not surprising I was a fat little kid back then.
I think “the future of awesome” really means “not quite awesome yet.” 😎

To be honest, I’m not sure if it was the Delaware Bay or the Chesapeake Bay but Tony and my father had these huge cages for catching crabs and we’d return [home](above%20the%20sub%20shop.md) with bushels of ’em.
and I know how to make one!

the rain never lies.content: When we discovered Sliding Rock, we had not bathed for days camping up in the mountains. The cold plunge pool below was totally rejuvenating.
